natural problem: A new green technology can be installed in your home for a one-time installation cost of $\$10,\!000$ and annual maintenance costs of $\$650$ per year. If the green technology is supposed to save you $\$1200$ each year in energy bills, how many whole years will it take to recuperate your costs?
natural solution: We look for the least number of years $n$ it takes for the savings to be greater than or equal to the costs. \begin{align} 1200n&\ge10,000+650n\quad\Rightarrow\\ 550n&\ge10,000\quad\Rightarrow\\ n&\ge\frac{10,000}{550}=18.\overline{18}
\end{align}The smallest integer greater than $18.\overline{18}$ is 19, so it will take $\boxed{19}$ years to recuperate the costs.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes installation_cost annual_maintenance_cost annual_saving years :: real
assumes h0 : "installation_cost = 10000"
and h1 : "annual_maintenance_cost = 650"
and h2 : "annual_saving = 1200"
shows  "years = (\<lceil> (installation_cost + annual_maintenance_cost * years - annual_saving * years) / (annual_saving - annual_maintenance_cost) \<rceil>)"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A new green technology can be installed in your home for a one-time installation cost of $\$10,\!000$ and annual maintenance costs of $\$650$ per year. If the green technology is supposed to save you $\$1200$ each year in energy bills, how many whole years will it take to recuperate your costs? The final Answer is 19
 ### Proof
 We look for the least number of years $n$ it takes for the savings to be greater than or equal to the costs. \begin{align} 1200n&\ge10,000+650n\quad\Rightarrow\\ 550n&\ge10,000\quad\Rightarrow\\ n&\ge\frac{10,000}{550}=18.\overline{18}
 \end{align}The smallest integer greater than $18.\overline{18}$ is 19, so it will take $\boxed{19}$ years to recuperate the costs.
 *)

theorem
fixes installation_cost annual_maintenance_cost annual_saving years :: real
assumes h0 : "installation_cost = 10000"
and h1 : "annual_maintenance_cost = 650"
and h2 : "annual_saving = 1200"
shows  "years = (\<lceil> (installation_cost + annual_maintenance_cost * years - annual_saving * years) / (annual_saving - annual_maintenance_cost) \<rceil>)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: A company is considering installing a new energy-saving system that costs $10,000 to install. The annual maintenance cost for the system is $650, while the system saves $1,200 in energy costs each year. How many years will it take for the company to break even on the investment, assuming no additional costs? Round up to the nearest year.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes installation_cost annual_maintenance_cost annual_savings :: real
assumes h0 : "installation_cost = 10000"
and h1 : "annual_maintenance_cost = 650"
and h2 : "annual_savings = 1200"
shows  "ceil ((installation_cost - annual_maintenance_cost) / (annual_savings - annual_maintenance_cost)) = 19"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A new green technology can be installed in your home for a one-time installation cost of $\$10,\!000$ and annual maintenance costs of $\$650$ per year. If the green technology is supposed to save you $\$1200$ each year in energy bills, how many whole years will it take to recuperate your costs? The final Answer is 19
 ### Proof
 We look for the least number of years $n$ it takes for the savings to be greater than or equal to the costs. \begin{align} 1200n&\ge10,000+650n\quad\Rightarrow\\ 550n&\ge10,000\quad\Rightarrow\\ n&\ge\frac{10,000}{550}=18.\overline{18}
 \end{align}The smallest integer greater than $18.\overline{18}$ is 19, so it will take $\boxed{19}$ years to recuperate the costs.
 *)

theorem
fixes installation_cost annual_maintenance_cost annual_savings :: real
assumes h0 : "installation_cost = 10000"
and h1 : "annual_maintenance_cost = 650"
and h2 : "annual_savings = 1200"
shows  "ceil ((installation_cost - annual_maintenance_cost) / (annual_savings - annual_maintenance_cost)) = 19"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: A homeowner installs a solar panel system that costs $10,000. The annual maintenance cost for the system is $650, and it saves the homeowner $1,200 per year in energy costs. How many years will it take for the homeowner to break even on the investment? Round up to the nearest whole year. The final answer is 19 years.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes installation_cost annual_maintenance_cost annual_energy_savings :: real
assumes h0 : "installation_cost = 10000"
and h1 : "annual_maintenance_cost = 650"
and h2 : "annual_energy_savings = 1200"
shows  "LEAST n. n * (annual_energy_savings - annual_maintenance_cost) >= installation_cost = 19"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A new green technology can be installed in your home for a one-time installation cost of $\$10,\!000$ and annual maintenance costs of $\$650$ per year. If the green technology is supposed to save you $\$1200$ each year in energy bills, how many whole years will it take to recuperate your costs? The final Answer is 19
 ### Proof
 We look for the least number of years $n$ it takes for the savings to be greater than or equal to the costs. \begin{align} 1200n&\ge10,000+650n\quad\Rightarrow\\ 550n&\ge10,000\quad\Rightarrow\\ n&\ge\frac{10,000}{550}=18.\overline{18}
 \end{align}The smallest integer greater than $18.\overline{18}$ is 19, so it will take $\boxed{19}$ years to recuperate the costs.
 *)

theorem
fixes installation_cost annual_maintenance_cost annual_energy_savings :: real
assumes h0 : "installation_cost = 10000"
and h1 : "annual_maintenance_cost = 650"
and h2 : "annual_energy_savings = 1200"
shows  "LEAST n. n * (annual_energy_savings - annual_maintenance_cost) >= installation_cost = 19"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: A new energy-saving system costs $10,000 to install and has an annual maintenance cost of $650. The system saves $1,200 per year on energy bills. How many years will it take for the savings to cover the installation cost? The final answer is 19 years.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes installation_cost annual_maintenance_cost annual_savings :: real
and years :: nat
assumes h0 : "installation_cost = 10000"
and h1 : "annual_maintenance_cost = 650"
and h2 : "annual_savings = 1200"
and h3 : "installation_cost + years * (annual_maintenance_cost - annual_savings) <= 0"
and h4 : "installation_cost + (years - 1) * (annual_maintenance_cost - annual_savings) > 0"
shows  "years = 19"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A new green technology can be installed in your home for a one-time installation cost of $\$10,\!000$ and annual maintenance costs of $\$650$ per year. If the green technology is supposed to save you $\$1200$ each year in energy bills, how many whole years will it take to recuperate your costs? The final Answer is 19
 ### Proof
 We look for the least number of years $n$ it takes for the savings to be greater than or equal to the costs. \begin{align} 1200n&\ge10,000+650n\quad\Rightarrow\\ 550n&\ge10,000\quad\Rightarrow\\ n&\ge\frac{10,000}{550}=18.\overline{18}
 \end{align}The smallest integer greater than $18.\overline{18}$ is 19, so it will take $\boxed{19}$ years to recuperate the costs.
 *)

theorem
fixes installation_cost annual_maintenance_cost annual_savings :: real
and years :: nat
assumes h0 : "installation_cost = 10000"
and h1 : "annual_maintenance_cost = 650"
and h2 : "annual_savings = 1200"
and h3 : "installation_cost + years * (annual_maintenance_cost - annual_savings) <= 0"
and h4 : "installation_cost + (years - 1) * (annual_maintenance_cost - annual_savings) > 0"
shows  "years = 19"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: A solar panel system costs $10,000 to install and has an annual maintenance cost of $650. The system saves $1,200 per year in energy costs. How many years does it take for the total savings to surpass the installation and maintenance costs? The final answer is 19 years.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes installation_cost annual_maintenance_cost annual_savings :: real
assumes h0 : "installation_cost = 10000"
and h1 : "annual_maintenance_cost = 650"
and h2 : "annual_savings = 1200"
shows  "let years_to_recuperate = (installation_cost + years * annual_maintenance_cost) / annual_savings in years_to_recuperate = 19"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A new green technology can be installed in your home for a one-time installation cost of $\$10,\!000$ and annual maintenance costs of $\$650$ per year. If the green technology is supposed to save you $\$1200$ each year in energy bills, how many whole years will it take to recuperate your costs? The final Answer is 19
 ### Proof
 We look for the least number of years $n$ it takes for the savings to be greater than or equal to the costs. \begin{align} 1200n&\ge10,000+650n\quad\Rightarrow\\ 550n&\ge10,000\quad\Rightarrow\\ n&\ge\frac{10,000}{550}=18.\overline{18}
 \end{align}The smallest integer greater than $18.\overline{18}$ is 19, so it will take $\boxed{19}$ years to recuperate the costs.
 *)

theorem
fixes installation_cost annual_maintenance_cost annual_savings :: real
assumes h0 : "installation_cost = 10000"
and h1 : "annual_maintenance_cost = 650"
and h2 : "annual_savings = 1200"
shows  "let years_to_recuperate = (installation_cost + years * annual_maintenance_cost) / annual_savings in years_to_recuperate = 19"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: A company installs a new system with an installation cost of $10,000. The annual maintenance cost for the system is $650, and it saves the company $1,200 per year. How many years will it take for the company to recuperate the initial investment and maintenance costs? The final answer is 19 years.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes installation_cost annual_maintenance_cost annual_savings :: real
fixes years :: nat
assumes h0 : "installation_cost = 10000"
and h1 : "annual_maintenance_cost = 650"
and h2 : "annual_savings = 1200"
and h3 : "years * annual_savings - years * annual_maintenance_cost = installation_cost"
shows  "years = 19"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A new green technology can be installed in your home for a one-time installation cost of $\$10,\!000$ and annual maintenance costs of $\$650$ per year. If the green technology is supposed to save you $\$1200$ each year in energy bills, how many whole years will it take to recuperate your costs? The final Answer is 19
 ### Proof
 We look for the least number of years $n$ it takes for the savings to be greater than or equal to the costs. \begin{align} 1200n&\ge10,000+650n\quad\Rightarrow\\ 550n&\ge10,000\quad\Rightarrow\\ n&\ge\frac{10,000}{550}=18.\overline{18}
 \end{align}The smallest integer greater than $18.\overline{18}$ is 19, so it will take $\boxed{19}$ years to recuperate the costs.
 *)

theorem
fixes installation_cost annual_maintenance_cost annual_savings :: real
fixes years :: nat
assumes h0 : "installation_cost = 10000"
and h1 : "annual_maintenance_cost = 650"
and h2 : "annual_savings = 1200"
and h3 : "years * annual_savings - years * annual_maintenance_cost = installation_cost"
shows  "years = 19"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: A company installs a new energy-saving system with an installation cost of $10,000. The system saves $1,200 per year in energy costs but requires $650 per year in maintenance. How many years will it take for the annual savings to offset the installation cost? The final answer is 19 years.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes installation_cost annual_maintenance_cost savings_per_year total_cost :: real
assumes h0 : "installation_cost = 10000"
and h1 : "annual_maintenance_cost = 650"
and h2 : "savings_per_year = 1200"
and h3 : "total_cost = (\<lambda>n. installation_cost + n * annual_maintenance_cost - n * savings_per_year)"
shows  "\<exists>n. n \<ge> 0 \<and> total_cost n \<le> 0 \<and> total_cost (n - 1) > 0"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A new green technology can be installed in your home for a one-time installation cost of $\$10,\!000$ and annual maintenance costs of $\$650$ per year. If the green technology is supposed to save you $\$1200$ each year in energy bills, how many whole years will it take to recuperate your costs? The final Answer is 19
 ### Proof
 We look for the least number of years $n$ it takes for the savings to be greater than or equal to the costs. \begin{align} 1200n&\ge10,000+650n\quad\Rightarrow\\ 550n&\ge10,000\quad\Rightarrow\\ n&\ge\frac{10,000}{550}=18.\overline{18}
 \end{align}The smallest integer greater than $18.\overline{18}$ is 19, so it will take $\boxed{19}$ years to recuperate the costs.
 *)

theorem
fixes installation_cost annual_maintenance_cost savings_per_year total_cost :: real
assumes h0 : "installation_cost = 10000"
and h1 : "annual_maintenance_cost = 650"
and h2 : "savings_per_year = 1200"
and h3 : "total_cost = (\<lambda>n. installation_cost + n * annual_maintenance_cost - n * savings_per_year)"
shows  "\<exists>n. n \<ge> 0 \<and> total_cost n \<le> 0 \<and> total_cost (n - 1) > 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: A company installs a new energy-saving system that costs $10,000 to install. The annual maintenance cost for the system is $650, while the system saves the company $1,200 per year in energy costs. How many years will it take for the total cost of the system, including installation and maintenance, to be less than or equal to the total savings?

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes initial_cost annual_maintenance_cost annual_savings years :: real
assumes h0 : "initial_cost = 10000"
and h1 : "annual_maintenance_cost = 650"
and h2 : "annual_savings = 1200"
shows  "\<exists>years. years = 19 \<and> initial_cost + annual_maintenance_cost * years \<le> annual_savings * years"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A new green technology can be installed in your home for a one-time installation cost of $\$10,\!000$ and annual maintenance costs of $\$650$ per year. If the green technology is supposed to save you $\$1200$ each year in energy bills, how many whole years will it take to recuperate your costs? The final Answer is 19
 ### Proof
 We look for the least number of years $n$ it takes for the savings to be greater than or equal to the costs. \begin{align} 1200n&\ge10,000+650n\quad\Rightarrow\\ 550n&\ge10,000\quad\Rightarrow\\ n&\ge\frac{10,000}{550}=18.\overline{18}
 \end{align}The smallest integer greater than $18.\overline{18}$ is 19, so it will take $\boxed{19}$ years to recuperate the costs.
 *)

theorem
fixes initial_cost annual_maintenance_cost annual_savings years :: real
assumes h0 : "initial_cost = 10000"
and h1 : "annual_maintenance_cost = 650"
and h2 : "annual_savings = 1200"
shows  "\<exists>years. years = 19 \<and> initial_cost + annual_maintenance_cost * years \<le> annual_savings * years"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: A solar panel installation has an initial cost of $10,000 and an annual maintenance cost of $650. The installation saves $1,200 per year on electricity costs. In how many years will the total savings be greater than or equal to the total cost of the installation and maintenance? The final answer is 19 years.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes installation_cost annual_maintenance_cost annual_savings :: real
assumes h0 : "installation_cost = 10000"
and h1 : "annual_maintenance_cost = 650"
and h2 : "annual_savings = 1200"
shows  "\<exists>years::nat. (years * annual_savings) - (years * annual_maintenance_cost) \<ge> installation_cost \<and> ((years - 1) * annual_savings) - ((years - 1) * annual_maintenance_cost) < installation_cost"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A new green technology can be installed in your home for a one-time installation cost of $\$10,\!000$ and annual maintenance costs of $\$650$ per year. If the green technology is supposed to save you $\$1200$ each year in energy bills, how many whole years will it take to recuperate your costs? The final Answer is 19
 ### Proof
 We look for the least number of years $n$ it takes for the savings to be greater than or equal to the costs. \begin{align} 1200n&\ge10,000+650n\quad\Rightarrow\\ 550n&\ge10,000\quad\Rightarrow\\ n&\ge\frac{10,000}{550}=18.\overline{18}
 \end{align}The smallest integer greater than $18.\overline{18}$ is 19, so it will take $\boxed{19}$ years to recuperate the costs.
 *)

theorem
fixes installation_cost annual_maintenance_cost annual_savings :: real
assumes h0 : "installation_cost = 10000"
and h1 : "annual_maintenance_cost = 650"
and h2 : "annual_savings = 1200"
shows  "\<exists>years::nat. (years * annual_savings) - (years * annual_maintenance_cost) \<ge> installation_cost \<and> ((years - 1) * annual_savings) - ((years - 1) * annual_maintenance_cost) < installation_cost"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: A new energy-efficient system costs $10,000 to install, saves $1,200 per year on energy bills, but requires an annual maintenance cost of $650. How many years will it take for the annual savings to cover the installation cost?

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes installation_cost annual_maintenance_cost annual_savings years :: real
assumes h0 : "installation_cost = 10000"
and h1 : "annual_maintenance_cost = 650"
and h2 : "annual_savings = 1200"
and h3 : "\<forall> years. years \<ge> 0 \<longrightarrow> installation_cost + (annual_maintenance_cost * years) \<le> annual_savings * years"
shows  "years = 19"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A new green technology can be installed in your home for a one-time installation cost of $\$10,\!000$ and annual maintenance costs of $\$650$ per year. If the green technology is supposed to save you $\$1200$ each year in energy bills, how many whole years will it take to recuperate your costs? The final Answer is 19
 ### Proof
 We look for the least number of years $n$ it takes for the savings to be greater than or equal to the costs. \begin{align} 1200n&\ge10,000+650n\quad\Rightarrow\\ 550n&\ge10,000\quad\Rightarrow\\ n&\ge\frac{10,000}{550}=18.\overline{18}
 \end{align}The smallest integer greater than $18.\overline{18}$ is 19, so it will take $\boxed{19}$ years to recuperate the costs.
 *)

theorem
fixes installation_cost annual_maintenance_cost annual_savings years :: real
assumes h0 : "installation_cost = 10000"
and h1 : "annual_maintenance_cost = 650"
and h2 : "annual_savings = 1200"
and h3 : "\<forall> years. years \<ge> 0 \<longrightarrow> installation_cost + (annual_maintenance_cost * years) \<le> annual_savings * years"
shows  "years = 19"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: A solar panel installation costs $10,000 upfront and has an annual maintenance cost of $650. It saves $1,200 per year on electricity bills. What is the minimum number of years the solar panels must be in operation for the total savings to be greater than or equal to the total cost? The final answer is 19 years.
